content.description: A good easy/warm up on jugs.
content.location: Climb the obvious jugs/buckets on the left side of the face.

content.description: This is a one and done type of problem but features a short, fun dyno. (Unless you happen to be really tall)
content.location: On the center left of the west face look for a rounded hueco at about head height. SDS directly below the hueco using a flat white sloper for the LH and a small sloping dish for the RH. Throw to the hueco and top out.

content.description: This problem climbs the tallest part of the shaded west face, thus the name. The rock is a bit sandy at the bottom but improves as height is gained. The upper part features some solid crimps.
content.location: Just to the right of center, SDS with the RH in a sandy sidepull pocket, LH in a sloping pocket. Bump the LH up to a good pocket, then make a long reach with the RH up to a small pocket/slot. Link to the topout using a sloping crimp for the LH and a sloper for the RH.

content.description: This problem climbs the overhanging lowball south face of this block. The rock quality isn't great but the holds are more or less solid. For full value start with your butt in the dirt rather than on a crashpad. The crux is keeping the feet from swinging off when moving to the lip, and because the ground rises up under the overhang it's easy to dab.
content.location: On the south overhang, left of center SDS with hands matched on a gaston. Move the RH up to a crimpy slot, then the LH to a flat crimp. All that's left then is to negotiate the topout.Â

content.description: This is a challenging problem that climbs the semi-prow dividing the west and south faces of this boulder. The stopper move is a precise stab into a 2 finger pocket.
content.location: SDS underneath the corner of the boulder with the RH in a pocket on the right side and the LH in a pocket on the left side. Move up to a flat white crimp that's dead center, then set up for the awkward stab to the 2 finger pocket with the LH. Once the 2 finger pocket is attained there is a good hold just above for the RH and then an easy topout.

content.description: Despite the name this boulder is somewhat of a hidden gem located in a beautiful cul-de-sac well away from the main concentration of boulders. Unfortunately, it features a higher amount of the kind of dirty, crumbly rock that's a hallmark of Texas Panhandle limestone than most of the other boulders here. Even so, it's solid enough to climb and the block is big enough to provide multiple lines.
